channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2012 The New York Times Company

item.title: United States and Israel Engage in Public Spat Over Iran Policy
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel criticized the Obama administration on Tuesday over recent statements that the United States would not set deadlines for Iran to halt its uranium enrichment activities.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel addressed reporters in Jerusalem on Tuesday.

item.title: Ceramic Fragments Point to Ice Age Artistry
item.description: A trove of fragments of fired clay found in a cave in Croatia suggest that humans of the ice age made ceramic art more regularly than believed.
item.dc:creator: By ALANNA MITCHELL
item.media:description: Archaeologists at Vela Spila, an island cave in Croatia, found dozens of ceramic shards that are 15,000 to 17,500 years old.

item.title: Movie Stirs Protest at U.S. Embassy in Cairo
item.description: A low-budget film of unknown origins, depicting Muhammad and Muslims in an unflattering light, inspired protesters to mass at the embassy and take down the American flag.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Protesters destroyed an American flag pulled down from the United States Embassy in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: NATO Helicopter Destroyed by Taliban
item.description: Three Afghan service personnel were killed on board the helicopter, which was parked inside Bagram Air Base.
item.dc:creator: By GRAHAM BOWLEY

item.title: Hungarians Hold Hunger Strike Over Voting Changes
item.description: The weeklong fast outside the Hungarian Parliament is the latest protest against the policies of the country’s prime minister, who has been accused of undermining Hungary’s young democracy.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: Detainee Who Died at Guantánamo Had Release Blocked by Court
item.description: Adnan Farhan Abdul Latif, a Yemeni man, was ordered freed in 2010 by a Federal District Court judge but remained in captivity after the ruling was overturned.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Egyptians Angry at Film Scale U.S. Embassy Walls
item.description: Some Egyptians who said they were protesting a film insulting to the Prophet Muhammad pulled down the American flag at the embassy in Cairo, witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: Protesters destroyed an American flag pulled down from the United States Embassy in Cairo on Tuesday.

item.title: Parliament Selects Mohamud as Somalia’s President
item.description: Hassan Sheik Mohamud will head a fledgling government that replaces the internationally backed transitional administration that had been trying to get Somalia on its feet.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Yemen: Airstrike Kills a Top Leader of Al Qaeda
item.description: An airstrike killed Saeed al-Shihri, a top leader of Al Qaeda’s branch in Yemen along with six others traveling with him in one car on Monday, American and Yemeni officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Cairo Journal: For Egyptians, No Relief From Cairo’s Infamous Traffic
item.description: Street vendors, erratic drivers, nonchalant traffic police officers: all contribute to a chaos in Cairo that is estimated to cost as much as $8 billion in lost productivity, delays and fuel waste.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Vendors clogged roads on Monday in Cairo.

item.title: Car Bomb Kills 12 in Yemen, but Targeted Minister Escapes Harm
item.description: A blast alongside a convoy of vehicles used by Yemen’s defense minister came one day after a top operative for Al Qaeda in the country was killed.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
item.dc:creator: By NASSER ARRABYEE and ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Yemeni soldiers gather at the site of a car bomb attack targeting the country's defense minister in Sana on Tuesday.

item.title: In France, Women Close to President Hollande Cause Stir
item.description: After a Twitter message by his current companion undermined his former partner, President François Hollande faces questions about how well he controls his personal life.
item.dc:creator: By MAÏA de la BAUME and STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Valérie Trierweiler, right, President François Hollande’s companion, shaking hands with Ségolène Royal, his former partner, in April. Their rivalry may reflect badly on his “normal” image.

item.title: Parwan Prison Transferred to Afghans, but Questions Remain
item.description: Top American commanders were absent from the ceremony marking the hand-over of Bagram prison to Afghan control, and even agreement on a crucial point of the signed prison deal itself was elusive.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Afghan prisoners, center, attended a ceremony handing over the Bagram prison to Afghan authorities on the outskirts of Kabul. After the ceremony, the prisoners were released.

item.title: Showdown Looms Over Planned Anti-Kremlin March
item.description: Parliament members found grounds to strip a lawmaker of his post, heightening tension days before another opposition march is planned for this weekend.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY

item.title: At War Blog: Eleven Years After 9/11, Afghanistan Still Matters
item.description: On an occasion when many Americans remember that terrible day in 2001, one Afghan asks that we remember his country too.
item.dc:creator: By JAVID AHMAD

item.title: The Lede Blog: After Militant Is Killed, Car Bomb Targets Yemen Minister
item.description: At least 12 people were killed in a car bombing in the capital of Yemen on Tuesday, in what appeared to be an attack targeting the country's defense minister.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula
American Enterprise Institute for Public Policy Research
item.dc:creator: By CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: Obama Nominates Robert Stephen Beecroft as Iraq Envoy
item.description: President Obama said he would nominate Robert Stephen Beecroft, a career diplomat, as the next ambassador to Iraq after his first choice, Brett H. McGurk, was forced to withdraw.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: British Police Evacuate Area Around Home of Alps Murder Victims
item.description: The British police on Monday evacuated an area around the home of a British-Iraqi family targeted in last week’s killing in the French Alps.
item.dc:creator: By SANDY MACASKILL and JOHN F. BURNS

item.title: In Mali, Islamists Maim Robbery Suspects
item.description: Radical Islamists in northern Mali cut off the hands and feet of four robbery suspects, while in southern Mali, the government was on the defensive after the army killed 16 preachers.
item.dc:creator: By ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: U.N. Details Flows of Syrian Refugees
item.description: in “an extraordinary acceleration,” the U.N. refugee agency said Tuesday, the number of people fleeing Syria jumped from 18,500 in June to 35,000 in July to 102,000 in August.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Syrian refugees on Tuesday at Jordan's Za'atri camp, which hosts 28,000 people displaced by the conflict.

item.title: China Accuses Japan of Stealing Disputed Islands
item.description: The charge comes after Japan bought the islands in the East China Sea for nearly $30 million from private owners.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: In Standoff Over Assange, Ecuadoreans Close Ranks
item.description: While some Ecuadoreans have only a vague idea of who Julian Assange is, they are clear in their pleasure that their country stood up to Britain in the asylum dispute.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: A family walks by graffiti in Quito that says, “Assange is coming ...” Julian Assange, the WikiLeaks founder, has taken refuge in Ecuador’s embassy in London.

item.title: Greece Names Nazi Reparations Panel
item.description: The move indicates the extent to which the shaky coalition government in Athens is trying to appease lawmakers from the extreme right and left.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: Occupy Hong Kong Protesters Forcibly Removed
item.description: The dismantling of the protest camp under HSBC’s Asia headquarters ends the last vestiges of what was once a global movement.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Palestinian Tax Increases Canceled in Move to Calm Protests
item.description: The Palestinian Authority’s announcement was aimed at ending protests in the West Bank, but a union leader rejected the concession and said street demonstrations would continue.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
